subject: BoJ minutes from March meeting states Japan's economic activity had been weak recently due mainly to the impact of the outbreak of COVID-19 and was likely to remain so for the time being mainly affected by the outbreak of the disease
content:
Says:

  • Several board members said consumer and household sentiment could sour rapidly if markets remain unstable.
  • Members concurred that the outlook for prices was likely to be somewhat weak for the time being, partly due to the effects of the decline in crude oil prices.
  • A few members said it was uncertain whether economy can make a strong rebound once virus was contained.
  • Members concurred that financial conditions in Japan were accommodative on the whole but had become less so, as seen partly in corporate financing such as the financial positions of small and medium-sized firms.

Full link: https://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/minu_2020/g200316.pdf
analysis_details: • As a reminder, at the meeting the BoJ kept rates at -0.10% and maintained the long-term yield target at 0% as expected but raised purchases of ETFs to JPY 12tln from JPY 6tln and J-REITS to JPY 180bln from JPY 90bln Ready to ease further without hesitation as needed with close eye on coronavirus. Furthermore, it  announced to set aside JPY 2tln for more buying of commercial paper and corporate bonds, although this was from the March emergency meeting and we have since had a more recent meeting earlier this week where the BoJ switched to unlimited bond buying and significantly increased maximum amount of additional purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper.

content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US COVID-19 cases 1,031,659 (prev. 1,005,147); death toll 60,057 (Prev. 57505). cases rose 1.2% which was the slowest this month. (Newswires)

US President Trump confirmed the US is planning to fast track the development of a coronavirus vaccine and that he is in charge of "Operation Warp Speed", which reportedly aims to rush a coronavirus vaccine and has a goal of 100mln doses by the end of 2020. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said G7 finance ministers held a call today to discuss COVID-19 responses, in which they discussed strategies to accelerate economic activity once economies reopen in-line with necessary health and safety measures. (Newswires)

White House is mulling plans to punish or demand financial compensation from China over COVID-19 handling with the measures being considered said to include asking for monetary damages, stripping China of sovereign immunity allowing it to be sued and considering the US cancelling part of its debt obligations to China, according to Washington Post. However, NEC Director Kudlow later denied that the US would cancel debt obligations to China. (Washington Post/CNBC)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 26,711 (Prev. 26,097). (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said we have passed the peak and are on a downward slope adding a comprehensive plan will be released next week on the reopening of the country. Furthermore, Johnson said austerity certainly will not be part of our approach in rebuilding public finances after the coronavirus pandemic. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said after a scientific update to the government, we don't want to relax social distancing measures in any way that could lead to an exponential spread of COVID-19 again. The spokesperson added that minds are focused on the May 7th date for the review of social distancing measures. (Newswires)

UK

EU

  • EU ECB Marginal Lending Rate 0.25% vs. Exp. 0.25% (Prev. 0.25%). (Newswires)
  • EU ECB Refinancing Rate (Apr) 0.00% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.00%)
  • EU ECB Deposit Rate (Apr) -0.50% vs. Exp. -0.50% (Prev. -0.50%)

ECB statement noted the Governing Council is fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed, while they are also ready to adjust all of its instruments as appropriate. ECB said conditions on the targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) have been further eased and announced to conduct a series of non-targeted pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations (PELTROs) to support liquidity conditions in the euro area financial system and contribute to preserving the smooth functioning of money markets by providing an effective liquidity backstop. Furthermore, PEPP purchases will continue to be conducted in a flexible manner over time across asset classes and among jurisdictions, while net purchases under the asset purchase programme (APP) will continue at a monthly pace of EUR 20bln, together with the purchases under the additional EUR 120bln temporary envelope until the end of the year.

ECB President Lagarde said the GC remains fully committed to doing everything in its mandate to support citizens through this challenging time and reiterated the ECB stands ready to adjust PEPP and all instruments as necessary, while she repeated her call for joint and coordinated policy actions between monetary and fiscal authorities. Furthermore, Lagarde stated that they did not discuss buying junk bonds under APP and noted that the combination of tools the ECB is currently using enables it to operate across the entire curve but noted that the ECB will use all flexibility that it has when asked about junk bonds and YCC. (Newswires)

Furthermore, it will include businesses with up to 15k employees vs. Prev. 10k and up to USD 5bln in annual revenue vs. Prev. USD 2.5bln, while under the new options, lenders would retain a 15% share on loans for borrowers requiring greater leverage. In related news, Fed’s Main Street lending programme will be priced off Libor after feedback from banks noted they were not ready to use SOFR, while demand for the loans may be limited by need for repayment. MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures were up in pre-markets by a decent amount, led by tech after decent earnings from MSFT, FB and QCOM after hours on Wednesday. However, by around the cash open, gains had been surrendered. A few reasons had been cited: month-end models favour equity selling/bond buying given the stocks rally seen in April; the mood in Europe was mixed at best ahead of the ECB, after oil major Shell cut its dividend, while banks were defensive after earnings from Societe Generale (GLE FP) and BBVA (BBVA  SM). Strategy-wise in the US, in April, small caps (RUT) have been among the top performers, with high dividend names also putting in a decent performance; minimum volatility and value strategies have lagged, although they are both still up around 10% in April (lagging ES which is up around 12% this month, while NQ is up around 15% in the month); some desks are now looking at stocks that have showed “positive linearity” (i.e. have given updates indicating that they have bounced back from the worst of COVID, or are seeing stability). The ECB meeting passed without much drama, with the central bank reiterating commitments to support the economy. On the data slate, weekly claims edged lower for a fourth straight week, while personal income and spending data showed the consumer under pressure in March (as expected, really). In aggregate, there hasn’t been much that has shifted the macro dial, and some profit-taking was cited, although major indices are still up a healthy amount this week. US FDA chief announced it is moving at “lightning speed” on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir experimental COVID-19 treatment. Intel (INTC) has reportedly launched its S-Series family of microprocessors targeted at gaming machines, increasing competition with AMD (AMD), according to Venture Beat. Boeing (BA) was cut from BBB to BBB-/stable at S&P. Meanwhile, BA is expected to launch a 7-tranche USD bond today. Exxon Mobil (XOM) maintained its quarterly dividend at USD 0.87/shr – its European peer Shell (RDSA LN) caught much attention today after announcing it would cut its dividend, the first oil major to do so. Disney (DIS) announced it is to move its “The Rise of the Skywalker” and “Artemis Fowl” to its Disney+ streaming service sooner than initially planned, according to WSJ. Zoom Video (ZM) admitted it does not have 300mln daily users; the same day it replaces Willis Tower Watson (WLTW) in the Nasdaq-100 index. SPX -0.9% at 2912, NDX +0.2% at 9001, DJIA -1.2% at 24,331.

A choppy session for the TPLEX, which had initially gotten off on the front-foot amid receding risk appetite, before reversing course into the settlement as IG corporate supply flooded. Disappointing GDP figures out of Europe, although expected, alongside month-end flows (read below) supported Treasuries heading into the US session. Another round of dire US data left the door open to inflows, and ECB’s Lagarde alluding to further stimulus to come. However, selling pressure began in the latter part of the session, in a steepening fashion. The selling pressure was likely a function of both month-end flows and corporate supply, where around ten IG issuers came to the dollar market as corporates emerge from the other side of earnings. Most notably, Boeing, who launched USD 25bln across seven tranches (3s, 5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s, 40s) with orders books reportedly reaching above USD 75bln for the - on average - T+450bps issue. IFR noted that April set a monthly IG issuance record of USD 288bln. By settlement, on the Treasury curve, 2s unch at 20bps, 10s unch at 63bps, 30s +3bps at 1.27%. Note that LIBOR continued to fall with the 3-month down by 13bps although nearby Eurodollars didn’t budge again today. US T-note futures (M0) settled 3 ticks higher at 139-02.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 30th: Stocks and USD sold amid month-end flows
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: ECB introduces PELTROs, otherwise stands pat; Month-end flows; jobless claims slightly better than feared, although PCE & Chicago PMI worse; White House mulling mass SPR purchases; FDA to speed-track remdesivir.
  • COMING UP: Data: UK, Canadian, US PMIs (Final), US ISM Manufacturing PMI & Construction Spending. Earnings: Exxon, Chevron, AbbVie, Colgate-Palmolive, Phillips 66, LyondellBasel.

MARKET WRAP

US Equity futures were up in pre-markets by a decent amount, led by tech after decent earnings from MSFT, FB and QCOM after hours on Wednesday. However, by around the cash open, gains had been surrendered. A few reasons had been cited: month-end models favour equity selling/bond buying given the stocks rally seen in April; the mood in Europe was mixed at best ahead of the ECB, after oil major Shell cut its dividend, while banks were defensive after earnings from Societe Generale (GLE FP) and BBVA (BBVA  SM). Strategy-wise in the US, in April, small caps (RUT) have been among the top performers, with high dividend names also putting in a decent performance; minimum volatility and value strategies have lagged, although they are both still up around 10% in April (lagging ES which is up around 12% this month, while NQ is up around 15% in the month); some desks are now looking at stocks that have showed “positive linearity” (i.e. have given updates indicating that they have bounced back from the worst of COVID, or are seeing stability). The ECB meeting passed without much drama, with the central bank reiterating commitments to support the economy. On the data slate, weekly claims edged lower for a fourth straight week, while personal income and spending data showed the consumer under pressure in March (as expected, really). In aggregate, there hasn’t been much that has shifted the macro dial, and some profit-taking was cited, although major indices are still up a healthy amount this week. Crude was higher ahead of OPEC production cuts starting on May 1st, while book-squaring has also been mentioned ahead of month-end. Elsewhere, Treasury yields and major curve spreads were little changed after a choppy session; the dollar has had a downside bias (month-end models also flagged USD selling), while gold has been finding the air thin above USD 1,700. After market, attention will be on heavy weights AAPL, AMZN, GILD and V.

VIRUS

GILEAD: NIH noted preliminary the results indicated patients who received remdesivir had a 31% faster recovery time than those with a placebo. The results also showed remdesivir accelerated recovery from advanced COVID-19 and suggested a survival benefit with a mortality rate of 8% for the group receiving the drug and 11.6% for those with a placebo, while median recovery time was 11 days for those with it compared to 15 days for those who received a placebo. The FDA Chief said they are moving ahead at lightning speed on the drug. RBC’s biotech analysts note that a rough estimate of Gilead’s target production suggests that there may just be enough to initially comfortably cover the volume represented by eligible patients in the US, assuming no problems, although it is “dependent on many highly variable and unknown factors.”

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB: The latest policy announcement from the ECB saw policymakers opt to stand pat on rates once again with the general train of thought at the Bank being that delving deeper into negative territory at this stage would provide little in the way of stimulus for the Eurozone. Instead, the Governing Council opted to sweeten the terms of the existing TLTROIII operations and launch a new series of non-targeted pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations (PELTROs) with the view of supporting liquidity conditions in the euro area. Those hoping for an expansion of the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) were left somewhat disappointed with the current envelope left at a size of EUR 750bln, whilst the asset purchase programme (APP) will continue to run at a monthly pace of EUR 20bln. That said, the Governing Council was explicit in informing market participants that it “is fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed”. Following the policy announcement, Pantheon Macroeconomics stated that their base case is for both the PEPP and QE programmes to be “extended through H1 2021, at least”. At the accompanying press conference, Lagarde provided a relatively cautious introductory statement as expected whilst stopping short of specific forecasts on the macro outlook; staff economic projections are not due until the June meeting. In-fitting with the policy announcement, Lagarde took every opportunity to remind those watching that the Governing Council will be there to help support the Eurozone economy, however policy will need to be carried out in a coordinated manner with fiscal authorities. Heading into the announcement some desk had speculated about the possibility of yield curve control (YCC), on which, Lagarde stated, the combination of tools the ECB is currently using enables it to operate across the entire curve; but noted ECB will use all flexibility that it has. Elsewhere, despite some slightly incoherent responses during the Q&A segment (in a bid to avoid any faux paus such as that seen in March), the press conference wasn’t too much of a game-changer for the narrative surrounding the Bank’s current course of action. In terms of what lies, ahead, Lagarde stated that so far there has been no discussion on purchasing junk bonds under APP and currently there has been no discussions on extending the PELTROs to non-banks, however, she again reiterated the ECB’s flexibility. Overall, Lagarde successfully managed to stick to the script that the Bank will utilise all of the tools at its disposal to help navigate the Eurozone economy through this crisis and avoid fragmentation. However, as opined by ING “in the current situation and in the next phase when the eurozone economy enters the recovery, the ECB will not be in the driver’s seat, fiscal policy will have to do the heavy work”.

FED: The Main Street Lening programme was expanded, as expected, today. The Fed is creating a third loan option with more risk sharing by lenders, lowering minimum loan size to USD 500k from USD 1mln, expanding scope and eligibility for the programme. To include businesses with up to 15k employees vs prev. 10k, and up to USD 5bln in annual revenue vs prev. USD 2.5bln. Under the new options, lenders would retain a 15% share on loans for borrowers requiring greater leverage. Fed is also expanding the pool of eligible businesses and said the start date is to be announced soon. One detail it mentioned was that the loans will be now based off of LIBOR, instead of the originally planned SOFR, as borrowers/banks said they were not prepared to use the proposed LIBOR replacement benchmark rate; this marks another blow to the transition to the SOFR rate.

NORTH AMERICA

CHINA: Overnight US President Trump noted the US is looking at different options regarding consequences for China for its handling of coronavirus crisis in which he suggested he could do a lot. This was later followed by a WaPo report suggesting the measures which are being considered are 1) asking for monetary damages, 2) stripping China of sovereign immunity, allowing it to be sued, 3) consider US cancelling part of its debt obligations to China. However, NEC Director Kudlow heavily rebuffed the third option saying it is “absolutely and unequivocally untrue”. The disputes between the US and China have been ongoing throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, with some nervous to whether a deuteriation in the relationship between the two could happen post COVID and thus impact trade. Note today traders reported that Chinese importers purchased 300k tonnes of Soybeans while Archer Daniel Midland (ADM) believes China will be increasing purchases of US agricultural goods as the year progresses and suggests as China moves towards honouring the USD 36bln of purchases, it is possible ethanol will enter the picture, particularly in Q4.

CRUDE

WTI (N0) SETTLED USD 2.73 HIGHER AT USD 21.85; BRENT (M0) EXPIRED USD 2.73 HIGHER AT USD 25.27/BBL, BRENT (N0) SETTLED USD 2.25 HIGHER AT USD 26.48/BBL.

Crude prices extended their solid gains on Thursday, despite wider risk aversion. Again, the market appears to be clawing back its losses, which were led by front-month WTI futures as participants baulked at taking delivery amid tight storage – a problem that is yet to be resolved. Perhaps the market is finding solace in comments from US Treasury Secretary Mncuhin, who late Wednesday said that the White House was looking at the ability to store another several hundred million barrels of oil. On a similar note, nine companies including, CVX and XOM (who both report earnings tomorrow), have agreed to rent space to store 23mln barrels of crude in the SPR. Furthermore, last night Norway’s Oil Ministry said it would be cutting output; cutting by 250k BOE/D in June and 134k in H2; additionally, the start-up of production at several fields will be delayed until 2021. Norway said that consequentially, production in December 2020 will be 300k BPD less than originally planned, although the regulation would cease by the year-end. The productive comments were countered by the Texas Railroad Commission Chairman Christian, who said there is still opposition to mandated oil production cuts, noting instead that state producers are already cutting output and that a 20% reduction in Texas will not impact global oil supplies. There were little new updates on the supply front on Thursday, although IEA’s Birol warned that global oil storage could be full by mid-June, calling on OPEC+ countries to consider further cuts. Note also that June Brent futures expire today, so there could be an element of book squaring in today’s tape action.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLE 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-02.

A choppy session for the TPLEX, which had initially gotten off on the front-foot amid receding risk appetite, before reversing course into the settlement as IG corporate supply flooded. Disappointing GDP figures out of Europe, although expected, alongside month-end flows (read below) supported Treasuries heading into the US session. Another round of dire US data left the door open to inflows, and ECB’s Lagarde alluding to further stimulus to come. However, selling pressure began in the latter part of the session, in a steepening fashion. The selling pressure was likely a function of both month-end flows and corporate supply, where around ten IG issuers came to the dollar market as corporates emerge from the other side of earnings. Most notably, Boeing, who launched USD 25bln across seven tranches (3s, 5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s, 40s) with orders books reportedly reaching above USD 75bln for the - on average - T+450bps issue. IFR noted that April set a monthly IG issuance record of USD 288bln. By settlement, on the Treasury curve, 2s unch at 20bps, 10s unch at 63bps, 30s +3bps at 1.27%. Note that LIBOR continued to fall with the 3-month down by 13bps although nearby Eurodollars didn’t budge again today.

MONTH-END: UBS notes large Treasury extension (0.14yrs) for the end-April rebalancing. UBS says this is higher than its 3-year end-April average (0.07yrs) and historical 3-month, 6-month, 12-month averages. “It is worth noting that this unusual large extension is a result of temporary change in the rebalancing rule last month and hence incomparable to historical extension.” The bank also estimates that month-end pension rebalancing could see USD 75-115bln equities sold, and reinvested into bonds, UBS says. Model predicts USD 90-140bln of US equity selling, versus USD 15-25bln of international equity buying.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.9% at 2912, NDX +0.2% at 9001, DJIA -1.2% at 24,331.

SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary +0.4%, Information Technology -0.45%, Real Estate -0.7%, Consumer Staples -1.1%, Industrials -2%, Energy -2.2%, Utilities -2.4%, Communications Svs -2.4%, Financials -2.7%, Materials -3%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: The US FDA chief announced it is moving at “lightning speed” on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir experimental COVID-19 treatment. Intel (INTC) has reportedly launched its S-Series family of microprocessors targeted at gaming machines, increasing competition with AMD (AMD), according to Venture Beat. Boeing (BA) was cut from BBB to BBB-/stable at S&P. Meanwhile, BA is expected to launch a 7-tranche USD bond today. Exxon Mobil (XOM) maintained its quarterly dividend at USD 0.87/shr – its European peer Shell (RDSA LN) caught much attention today after announcing it would cut its dividend, the first oil major to do so. Disney (DIS) announced it is to move its “The Rise of the Skywalker” and “Artemis Fowl” to its Disney+ streaming service sooner than initially planned, according to WSJ. Zoom Video (ZM) admitted it does not have 300mln daily users; the same day it replaces Willis Tower Watson (WLTW) in the Nasdaq-100 index.

EARNINGS: Microsoft (MSFT) beat on EPS and revenue. Its breakdown of revenues was also solid with its Azure revenue growth at 39%, supporting the cloud server revenues. McDonald’s (MCD missed on EPS, although beat on revenue, while SSS declined amid mass closures, it did note it began the year with exceptionally strong momentum. Tesla (TSLA) beat on EPS and revenue was in line. TSLA expects Model 3 production to reach 4k a week by the middle of the year while remaining committed to its Model Y expansion. Qualcomm (QCOM) beat on top and bottom line although MSM chip shipments fell 17% Y/Y to 129mln. Q3 EPS guidance was firmer than expected. Facebook (FB) rallied after a beat on advertising revenue while DAU’s and MAU’s surged amid COVID-19, beating expectations. FB also noted it has seen some signs of stabilisation. Twitter (TWTR) missed on EPS and printed an unexpected loss per share while its advertising revenue and DAU’s were more or less in line with expectations.

DATA

US JOBLESS CLAIMS: US weekly initial jobless claims lower for the fourth straight week; it may be mid-June before claims fall beneath 1mln, Pantheon Macroeconomics says. Weekly initial jobless claims data for the w/e April 25th saw the headline at 3.84mln, topping the consensus 3.5mlnl continuing claims, however, came in lower than expected at 17.99mln - the Street was looking for 19.24mln. Pantheon Macroeconomics said that the data is still terrible, but a little bit less terrible than last week. “Claims have now fallen by 3.0M from the peak, in the week ended March 28thth, but the 588K drop this week is the smallest in three weeks, and the weekly level is still nearly six times higher than in the worst single week after the crash of 2008.” The consultancy says its proxies imply claims will fall again next week, to around 3.1mln. Pantheon believes that layoffs are now working through supply chains and services firms, away from the front-line consumer-facing businesses which laid off so many people when the lockdowns began. “We reckon claims will dip below 1mln by mid-June, with a total increase of 11mln-to-12mln between the April and May payroll survey weeks.” NOTE: This week’s data will not factor into the BLS employment situation report for April, released May 8th - last week’s claims data served coincided with the survey period.

US CONSUMER SPENDING: US consumer spending froze in March; April likely to be even worse, Oxford Economics says. Consumer spending fell by the largest monthly amount on record (personal consumption -7.5% M/M against an expected -5.0%; personal income -2.0% M/M against an expected -1.5%). “The combination of massive layoffs, reduced hours worked, curbed salaries and financial turmoil led to a steep 2.0% decline in disposable income – the largest since 2013 – which was only partially offset by greater benefit payments,” Oxford Economics says. Consumers were building their savings (the savings rate to the highest since 1975 at 13.1%, from 8.2%). The PCE data was more stable, with the core M/M falling 0.1% in line with the consensus, while the Y/Y core rate rose 0.1ppts to 1.7%; in the coming months, OxEco expects the strong disinflationary impulse from the virus fallout to lead to deflation for headline PCE and the weakest core PCE inflation on record. “The coronavirus fear, the social distancing measures, the financial volatility and plummeting confidence have taken a severe toll on consumers’ ability and willingness to spend,” the consultancy writes, “we estimate household outlays will likely contract around 15% in Q2, or nearly 50% annualised, with services outlays down nearly 20%, or roughly 60% annualised.”

CHICAGO PMI: In April headline PMI declined to 35.4 to its lowest level since March 2009 spurred by a drop in Business confidence, the report notes. Production fell 19 points to the lowest level since June 1980 while New Orders saw the steepst decline on record after COVID-19 hits both demand and production. Employment fell to 11.1 point, lowest since June 2009 while prices dipped beneath 50 after a 14.6-point decline to the lowest level since March 2016. Elsewhere, the report notes inventories rose for a 9th consecutive month but remains beneath the 50.0 mark.

FOREX

Month-end sees dollar sell off support the EURO

USD: The greenback tumbled on Thursday with many month-end rebalancing models pointing towards dollar selling. The DXY crossed beneath 99 at one point before gradually paring back slightly from the extremes.

EUR: With the ECB somewhat disappointing (some investors had hoped for an expansion of the PEPP and/or APP, although it did introduce “PELTRO” and eased the measures on its LTRO III programme). The single currency firmed over the course of the session, despite Bund/BTP spreads widening. However, despite the aforementioned factors, the month-end dollar selling clearly dominated price action, and helped support the single currency to highs of 1.0971.

CYCLICALS (AUD, NZD, GBP, CAD): Cyclicals were mixed: the AUD succumbed to downbeat risk sentiment, as major equity indices fell. Even with USD selling heavily, the Aussie failed to reap the same benefits as others, particularly GBP which rallied heading into the London fix. CAD also saw weakness, though USDCAD remains sub-1.40 as oil prices ticked up. Kiwi seemed to benefit from the USD selling pressures.

COMMODITY FX (RUB, NOK): WTI and Brent continued to rebound on Thursday, supported by the reports from Norway that it is cut oil output, and US policymakers hinting at support for the energy sector. Despite oil upside, the RUB weakened, underperforming the EMFX complex, perhaps as a result of its PM being diagnosed with the coronavirus. ING noted that the RUB looks the most attractive among commodity exporters due to its relatively solid fiscal position. NOK traded flat against the Euro today, with ING’s strategists suggesting that upside will be limited and EURNOK should remain above 11.00.

EMFX:  EMFX couldn’t stage a rally, despite the USD weakness, as other risk benchmarks were struggling. ZAR saw weakness after South Africa was downgraded deeper into Junk by S&P, which cited the impact of COVID-19.  TRY was also weaker, although not to the same extent as other EMFX; the CBRT noted that it is in discussions with other central banks about swap lines, and it cut its year end inflation forecast to 7.4% from 8.2%.

CRUDE WRAP: WTI (N0) settles USD 2.73 higher at USD 21.85; Brent (M0) expires USD 2.73 higher at USD 25.27/bbl, Brent (N0) settles USD 2.25 higher at USD 26.48/bbl
analysis_details: • Crude prices extended their solid gains on Thursday, despite wider risk aversion. Again, the market appears to be clawing back its losses, which were led by front-month WTI futures as participants baulked at taking delivery amid tight storage – a problem that is yet to be resolved. Perhaps the market is finding solace in comments from US Treasury Secretary Mncuhin, who late Wednesday said that the White House was looking at the ability to store another several hundred million barrels of oil. On a similar note, nine companies including, CVX and XOM (who both report earnings tomorrow), have agreed to rent space to store 23mln barrels of crude in the SPR. Furthermore, last night Norway’s Oil Ministry said it would be cutting output; cutting by 250k BOE/D in June and 134k in H2; additionally, the start-up of production at several fields will be delayed until 2021. Norway said that consequentially, production in December 2020 will be 300k BPD less than originally planned, although the regulation would cease by the year-end. The productive comments were countered by the Texas Railroad Commission Chairman Christian, who said there is still opposition to mandated oil production cuts, noting instead that state producers are already cutting output and that a 20% reduction in Texas will not impact global oil supplies. There were little new updates on the supply front on Thursday, although IEA’s Birol warned that global oil storage could be full by mid-June, calling on OPEC+ countries to consider further cuts. Note also that June Brent futures expire today, so there could be an element of book squaring in today’s tape action.

Daily FX Wrap: ECB and Fed both in action on the final day of the month
content:
DXY

It looks like the touted peak or last-ditch Dollar selling for the end of April did come towards the end of Thursday’s EU session as the index plumbed lows below 99.000 having remained relatively resilient close to 99.500 through more weak US data (weekly claims), worrying survey news (Chicago PMI) and even when the Fed enhanced its Main Street lending facility via expanding the scope and eligibility after hints to that effect from Chair Powell yesterday. However, the Buck clawed back losses vs riskier and high beta currencies as the mood soured amidst final month asset rebalancing in favour of bonds over stocks.   

EUR

Aside from knee-jerks during ECB President Lagarde’s post-policy meeting press conference that highlighted unprecedented economic contraction caused by COVID-19 and pronounced downside for inflation as a result, the Euro was also remarkably resolute and rebounded firmly from around 1.0834 vs Greenback to eclipse last week’s peak just under 1.0900 on the way through 1.0950. To recap, the ECB sweetened its TLTRO3 terms via lower rates and added new liquidity repos in the form of PELTROs, but left all benchmark rates unchanged along with the QE envelope and PEPP, albeit with the usual pledge to offer more stimulus if needed.

GBP/CHF/NZD

The Pound was clear beneficiary of bullish seasonal factors allied to the aforementioned month end Dollar flogging, as Cable flew beyond 1.2500 and then 1.2600, while Eur/Gbp reversed further from recent peaks over the 200 DMA to sub-0.8700 again. Similarly, the Franc made significant gains at the expense of its US rival and roared back from circa 0.9760 to 0.9640, while the Kiwi regrouped on the 0.6100 handle and unwound declines relative to its Aussie neighbour after Aud/Nzd failed to reach 1.0700 and Aud/Usd ran into option-related offers at 0.6570 (2.7 bn expired today) that thwarted a breach of the 100 DMA (0.6567).

CAD/JPY

The Loonie posted a new mtd best vs its US counterpart with the aid of an extended bounce in crude, but was undermined by Canadian data (GDP and retail sales) and retraced from 1.3850 to 1.3912 at worst, while the Yen appears to have paid the price for not sustaining momentum through a key Fib retracement level as Usd/Jpy spiked from 106.42 to 107.20 before paring back.

SCANDI/EM

Choppy trade across the board, but the Sek and Nok are retaining upward trajectories vs the Eur following another, albeit minor rise in Norges Bank daily purchases of the Krona vs foreign currencies starting from tomorrow and until the end of May. Conversely, most EMs are depreciating, with the Try not helped by the CBRT lowering its inflation forecast for the end of 2020 and Zar ultimately under pressure after S&P cut SA’s rating further below junk.

subject: Fed is creating a third loan option with more risk sharing by lenders, lowering minimum loan size to USD 500k from USD 1mln, expanding scope and eligibility for "main street lending" programme
content:
• To include businesses with up to 15k employees vs. Prev. 10k and up to USD 5bln in annual revenue vs. Prev. USD 2.5bln
  • Under the new options, lenders would retain a 15% share on loans for borrowers requiring greater leverage
  • Borrowers under "main street" programme will commit to follow compensation, stock buyback and dividend rules applied to direct loan under the Care Act and will make "commercially reasonable efforts" to maintain payroll
  • Also expanding pool of eligible businesses
  • Repeats it will be backstopped with USD 75bln of Treasury risk capital, which will provide USD 600bln in loans
  • Start date to be announced soon

subject: US EQUITY OPEN: Indices open lower although NDX marginally higher thanks to gains in MSFT, TSLA & FB post earnings
analysis_details:
MACRO SNAPSHOT: Asia traded with a positive tone, despite soft PMI data out of China (non-mfg PMI up; mfg PMI down, and new export orders were grim); but Europe is lower across the region; banking names were hit after the ECB and soft trading updates from Societe Generale, and BBVA earnings underwhelmed. US equity index futures were initially firmer, although have now entered negative territory in line with Europe post ECB, with Nasdaq-100 still just in the green after decent updates from big tech in the last couple of days. Treasury yields are lower, with most of the action in the belly, while major curve spreads are mixed. The USD and gold are roughly flat.  

SECTORS: The majority of sectors open in negative territory, with losses led by Financials amid lower yields across the curve. Materials are also lagging, with Dow (DOW) weighing after poor earnings. Communication Services are outperforming being propped by gains in Facebook (FB) following a solid earnings report released Wednesday AMC.  

STOCK SPECIFICS: The US FDA chief announced it is moving at “lighting speed” on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir experimental COVID-19 treatment. Intel (INTC) has reportedly launched its S-Series family of microprocessors targeted at gaming machines, increasing competition with AMD (AMD), according to Venture Beat. Boeing (BA) was cut from BBB to BBB-/stable at S&P. Meanwhile, the BA is expected to launch a 7-tranche USD bond today. Exxon Mobil (XOM) maintained its quarterly dividend at USD 0.87/shr – it’s European peer Shell (RDSA LN) caught much attention today after announcing it would cut its dividend, the first oil major to do so. Disney (DIS) announced it is to move its “The Rise of the Skywalker” and “Artemis Fowl” to its Disney+ streaming service sooner than initially planned, according to WSJ. Zoom Video (ZM) admitted it does not have 300mln daily users.  EARNINGS: Microsoft (MSFT) beat on EPS and revenue. Its breakdown of revenues was also solid with its Azure revenue growth at 39%, supporting the cloud server revenues. McDonalds (MCD missed on EPS, although beat on revenue, while SSS declined amid mass closures, it did note it began the year with exceptionally strong momentum. Tesla (TSLA) beat on EPS and revenue was in line. TSLA expects Model 3 production to reach 4k a week by the middle of the year while remaining committed to its Model Y expansion. Qualcomm (QCOM) beat on top and bottom line although MSM chip shipments fell 17% Y/Y to 129mln. Q3 EPS guidance was firmer than expected. Facebook (FB) rallied after a beat on advertising revenue while DAU’s and MAU’s surged amid COVID-19, beating expectations. FB also noted it has seen some signs of stabilization. 

WATCH THE ENERGY SECTOR: Energy is also in focus after Norway officially said it would cut output late Wednesday. After hours, XOM also said it would be maintaining its dividend, although its European peer Shell (RDSA LN) this morning became the first oil major to cut its dividend in the COVID-19 fallout, and is seeing downside in European trade. Also, US President Trump announced that a plan to help oil companies was coming shortly. Additionally, nine companies including CVX and XOM have agreed to rent space to store 23mln barrels of crude in the SPR, Reuters reported.  

JPM EARNINGS TRACKER: JPMorgan’s earnings season tracker points to negative surprises in the US of -2%, despite consensus expectations which looked for double-digit EPS falls at the beginning of the quarter. “In contrast to past quarters, where the earnings integer would inflect higher once the reporting started, blended Q1 '20e EPS growth for S&P500 continues to move lower, currently at $32, down from $40 at the start of the year” the bank writes. JPM notes that nominally in the US, 65% of S&P 500 companies beat EPS estimates, but this ratio is the lowest in at least a decade; EPS growth is around -16% Y/Y which is about 2% below consensus. The bank observes that earnings delivery for Financials is very weak, down nearly 50% Y/Y, but ex-Financials EPS growth in the S&P 500 is flat this quarter Y/Y. Meanwhile, Cyclicals are also printing negative growth, while Defensives have fared better. Revenue growth is flat, with 66% of companies beating estimates. Aftermarket, earnings from AAPL (preview here), AMZN (preview here), and V (preview here) are eyed.    

 LINEARITY/STYLES: Some desks note that, stylistically, companies that have reported positive “linearity” (i.e. have shown early signs of bouncing back from pandemic – like GOOG and FB, who both reported advertising trends had improved after the initial downside) are likely to be rewarded, even if the incoming metrics are still on the soft side. US equities saw a pro-cyclical twist on Tuesday, with investors selling momentum and growth, although the big tech earnings in the last couple of days may help stabilise that trend.

ANALYSIS: US weekly initial jobless claims lower for the fourth straight week; may be mid-June before claims fall beneath 1mln, Pantheon Macroeconomics says
content:
• Weekly initial jobless claims data for the w/e 25th April saw the headline at 3.84mln, topping the consensus 3.5mlnl continuing claims, however, came in lower than expected at 17.99mln - the Street was looking for 19.24mln.
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics said that the data is still terrible, but a little bit less terrible than last week. "Claims have now fallen by 3.0M from the peak, in the week ended March 28, but the 588K drop this week is the smallest in three weeks, and the weekly level is still nearly six times higher than in the worst single week after the crash of 2008." The consultancy says its proxies imply claims will fall again next week, to around 3.1mln.
  • Pantheon believes that layoffs are now working through supply chains and services firms, away from the front-line consumer-facing businesses which laid off so many people when the lockdowns began. "We reckon claims will dip below 1mln by mid-June, with a total increase of 11mln-to-12mln between the April and May payroll survey weeks."
  • NOTE: This week's data will not factor into the BLS employment situation report for April, released 8th May - last week's claims data served coincided with the survey period.

subject: ANALYSIS: US consumer spending froze in March; April likely to be even worse, Oxford Economics says
content:
• Consumer spending fell by the largest monthly amount on record (personal consumption -7.5% M/M against an expected -5.0%; personal income -2.0% M/M against an expected -1.5%).
  • "The combination of massive layoffs, reduced hours worked, curbed salaries and financial turmoil led to a steep 2.0% decline in disposable income – the largest since 2013 – which was only partially offset by greater benefit payments," Oxford Economics says. Consumers were building their savings (the savings rate to the highest since 1975 at 13.1%, from 8.2%)
  • The PCE data was more stable, with the core M/M falling 0.1% in line with the consensus, while the Y/Y core rate rose 0.1ppts to 1.7%; in the coming months, OxEco expects the strong disinflationary impulse from the virus fallout to lead to deflation for headline PCE and the weakest core PCE inflation on record.
  • "The coronavirus fear, the social distancing measures, the financial volatility and plummeting confidence have taken a severe toll on consumers’ ability and willingness to spend," the consultancy writes, "we estimate household outlays will likely contract around 15% in Q2, or nearly 50% annualised, with services outlays down nearly 20%, or roughly 60% annualised."

subject: ECB PRESS CONFERENCE [ROLLING HEADLINE]
content:
OUTLOOK

  • GDP could fall between 5-12% this year, depending on duration of containment measures and policies to mitigate the consequences
  • Speed of recovery is uncertain
  • Europe is facing a recession of unprecedented magnitude

COORDINATED POLICY

  • Repeats call for joint and coordinated policy actions between monetary and fiscal authorities

MEASURES

  • Governing Council remains fully committed to doing everything in its mandate to support citizens through this challenging time
  • When asked about YCC, says the combination of tools the ECB is currently using enables it to operate across the entire curve; but says ECB will use all flexibility that it has
  • Reiterates ECB stands ready to adjust PEPP and all instruments as necessary [MENTIONED IN THE STATEMENT]

PELTRO

  • Did not discuss extending PELTRO beyond banks, though she again reiterated the ECB's flexibility, and did not rule out lending to non-banks in the future, citing extraordinary times
  • Will comprise of seven refinancing operations from May 2020, maturing in a staggered manner from July-Sep 2021; will be carried out as fixed rate tendered operations, full allotment [MENTIONED IN THE STATEMENT]

PEPP

  • PEPP is a stand-alone, exceptional programme which is targeted, temporary and flexible
  • Might extend PEPP beyond end-2020
  • When asked about the OMT, says PEPP programme is more suited to the current situation [Note: some analysts have suggested that the OMT programme has already been made redundant by the ECB's PEPP.]
  • Will apply the same detail on PEPP as it does on APP, but every two months; says ECB will not tolerate any risk of fragmentation
  • ECB will continue PEPP purchases until COVID-19 crisis phase is over, but in any case, until the end of 2020 [MENTIONED IN THE STATEMENT]

JUNK BONDS

  • Did not discuss buying junk bonds under APP

subject: FDA Head says it is moving at “lighting speed” on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir
analysis_details:
• Last night, US President Trump stated Gilead (GILD) results are a building block and that he wants FDA to go as quickly as it can on possible approval of Remdesivir as a coronavirus treatment. 
  • NIH stated preliminary Gilead (GILD) remdesivir results indicate patients who received the drug had a 31% faster recovery time than those with a placebo.  
  • It showed remdesiviir accelerated recovery from advanced COVID-19. 
  • The preliminary results suggested a survival benefit with a mortality rate of 8% for the group receiving remdesivir vs 11.6% for those with a placebo  Median recovery times was 11 days for those with remdesivir, compared to 15 days for those who received a placebo

subject: ECB's Lagarde says it will apply the same detail on PEPP as it does on APP, but every two months; says ECB will not tolerate any risk of fragmentation
ECB President Lagarde, asked about YCC, says the combination of tools the ECB is currently using enables it to operate across the entire curve; but says ECB will use all flexibility that it has
analysis_details:
• Lagarde seems to be dismissing YCC policy tool at this stage; this policy has been adopted by the BOJ and RBA, with the FOMC expected to follow suit in the months ahead.
  • The tool could be combined with a central bank's pledge to keep rates low for longer, allowing it to 'control' yields more closely

subject: Fixed and FX update: US data largely shrugged off in favour of Lagarde
content: Once again worse than forecast US jobless claims and an upward revision to the previous week’s initial tally have been somewhat overlooked on the basis that it could have been worse given the circumstances, but stagnant Canadian growth and significantly weaker than expected retail sales have sapped a bit more Loonie strength within a 1.3910-1.3850 range vs its US counterpart. Meanwhile, Bunds are edging closer to 174.00, but the big bond move since the ECB President started her presser has been in BTPs that spiked to 139.77 at best without anything obvious to prompt the resurgence in her prepared text. Perhaps PEPP or even extra BoI buying under the guise of normal QE will be framed for the pronounced price recovery that has subsequently faded, and appreciably.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: Bunds cheer new ECB efforts, but BTPs unimpressed
content: The Euro remains extremely steady in wake of fresh policy stimulus from the ECB aimed at enhancing liquidity provisions and lowering funding costs, but Eurozone bonds gleaned more upside momentum awaiting President Lagarde’s post-meeting press conference with the notable exception of Italian debt that hit new intraday lows just under 137.50 before reflection and paring some losses. Meanwhile, the Dollar is still trying to withstand bouts of month-end rebalancing offers with the DXY just off a new 99.342 base, and now braced for weekly initial claims.

ECB ONE-LINER: keeps policy settings unchanged, but reiterates willingness to do more; makes TLTRO conditions more favourable, launches new PLTRO

ECB STATEMENT: Governing Council is fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed; Ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate
content:
• (1) The conditions on the targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) have been further eased.
  • (2) A new series of non-targeted pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations (PELTROs) will be conducted to support liquidity conditions in the euro area financial system and contribute to preserving the smooth functioning of money markets by providing an effective liquidity backstop.
  • (3) PEPP purchases will continue to be conducted in a flexible manner over time, across asset classes and among jurisdictions.
  • (4) Net purchases under the asset purchase programme (APP) will continue at a monthly pace of EUR 20bln, together with the purchases under the additional EUR 120bln temporary envelope until the end of the year
  • (5) Reinvestments of the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP will continue, in full
  • (6) Rates unchanged, Forward guidance unchanged

Further details on the amendments made to the terms of TLTRO III and on the new PELTROs will be published in dedicated press releases this afternoon at 15:30 CET.

Global fund managers recommend increasing bond holdings, cut stocks; see U-shaped recovery, according to a Reuters Poll
content:
• A survey of 34 fund managers recommend cutting equity allocations to 45.1% (prev. 45.9%) - the lowest in seven months
  • fund managers recommend increasing bond holdings to 43.3% (prev. 43.1% last month)
  • The poll quoted a fund manager stating "recent moves in stocks are not justified by any concrete development either in the form of a vaccine breakthrough or on the economic front"
  • Fund managers see a U-shape recovery, with a long bottom phase and a slow recovery at end-2020/start-2021, but that depends on the progress of combating the virus; gradual normalisation is the base case. 
  • NOTE: month-end rebalancing models are tending to suggest negative equities/positive bonds given the rally seen in stocks through April

subject: South African National Treasury sees 2020 contraction of 5.8% and 4% growth in 2021, according to a presentation to Parliament's Finance Committee
US PRE-MARKET MACRO: Big tech earnings supportive; AAPL, AMZN after market; Energy sector in focus; Ahead, jobless claims, PCE, ECB eyed
analysis_details:
• MACRO SNAPSHOT: Asia traded with a positive tone, despite soft PMI data out of China (non-mfg PMI up; mfg PMI down, and new export orders were grim); but Europe has a mixed feel across the region; banking names are a little softer after a soft trading update from Societe Generale, and BBVA earnings underwhelmed. US equity index futures were firmer, although have now begun edging into the red, with Nasdaq-100 still just in the green after decent updates from big tech in the last couple of days. Treasury yields are lower, with most of the action in the belly, while major curve spreads are mixed. The USD and gold are roughly flat.
  • US STOCKS: Nasdaq-100 futures are outperforming in the pre-market, following a decent reporting slate aftermarket on Wednesday, which had a tech-heavy feel: positive update from MSFT (cloud supporting during the pandemic), FB (saw stability in advertising trends in April after weak March – similar to what GOOG said this week); QCOM (China smartphone demand is almost fully restored), while TSLA (made money in Q1),and EBAY (also benefiting from pandemic). In energy, last night XOM maintained its dividend (European peer, Shell, cut its this morning).
  • WATCH THE ENERGY SECTOR: Energy is also in focus after Norway officially said it would cut output late Wednesday. After hours, XOM also said it would be maintaining its dividend, although its European peer Shell (RDSA LN) this morning became the first oil major to cut its dividend in the COVID-19 fallout, and is seeing downside in European trade. Also, US President Trump announced that a plan to help oil companies was coming shortly. Additionally, nine companies including CVX and XOM have agreed to rent space to store 23mln barrels of crude in the SPR, Reuters reported.
  • JPM EARNINGS TRACKER: JPMorgan’s earnings season tracker points to negative surprises in the US of -2%, despite consensus expectations which looked for double-digit EPS falls at the beginning of the quarter. “In contrast to past quarters, where the earnings integer would inflect higher once the reporting started, blended Q1 '20e EPS growth for S&P500 continues to move lower, currently at $32, down from $40 at the start of the year” the bank writes. JPM notes that nominally in the US, 65% of S&P 500 companies beat EPS estimates, but this ratio is the lowest in at least a decade; EPS growth is around -16% Y/Y which is about 2% below consensus. The bank observes that earnings delivery for Financials is very weak, down nearly 50% Y/Y, but ex-Financials EPS growth in the S&P 500 is flat this quarter Y/Y. Meanwhile, Cyclicals are also printing negative growth, while Defensives have fared better. Revenue growth is flat, with 66% of companies beating estimates. Aftermarket, earnings from AAPL (preview here), AMZN (preview here), and V (preview here) are eyed.   
  • LINEARITY/STYLES: Some desks note that, stylistically, companies that have reported positive “linearity” (i.e. have shown early signs of bouncing back from pandemic – like GOOG and FB, who both reported advertising trends had improved after the initial downside) are likely to be rewarded, even if the incoming metrics are still on the soft side. US equities saw a pro-cyclical twist on Tuesday, with investors selling momentum and growth, although the big tech earnings in the last couple of days may help stabilise that trend.  
  • DATA: Also on the radar today is the weekly initial jobless claims data (0830 ET/1330 BST), which is expected to see a fourth consecutive lower print (preview here). Additionally, personal income/spending/PCE (0830 ET/1330 BST) is likely to show a hit as lockdowns began in March (preview here).
  • ECB: Rate decision at 1245BST/0645CDT, press conference 1330BST/0730CDT. Rates set to be left unchanged, tweaks to the PEPP could be on the cards. President Lagarde likely to stress the Governing Council’s willingness to “do whatever it takes” in the absence of any other policy adjustments. (Preview here)

PRIMER: US Personal income, spending, PCE due at 0830 ET/1330 BST; downside expected as lockdowns came into effect
content:
Personal income is seen falling 1.5% M/M in March; consumption is expected to drop by 5%. Personal income and spending are likely to have been hit after lockdowns began in March; retail sales data for March suggests a sharp decline. Additionally, labour market income fell in the March jobs report, and Credit Suisse thinks this still dramatically understated the extent of the labour market weakness.

Core PCE is seen -0.1% M/M and 1.6% Y/Y (from a prior 1.8% Y/Y); that Y/Y gauge may be supported by base effects, analysts say. Inflation pressures were also weak in March, with shutdown sectors seeing large price declines. In terms of the implications for policy, Fed’s Powell on Wednesday said that as long as inflation expectations remain anchored the US should not see deflation. He also reiterated the FOMC’s support for the economy, and pledged that it would not be withdrawn any time soon.

PRIMER: US Initial Jobless Claims due at 0830 ET/1330 BST; Street sees weekly claims lower for the fourth straight week
content:
• The Street looks for weekly initial jobless claims (w/e 25th April) to print 3.5mln (range: 2mln to 5mln), and continuing claims are seen rising to 19.24mln (range: 16.43mln to 20.5mln).
  • After last week’s 4.43mln initial jobless claims, the cumulative tally over the last five weeks has risen to 26.45mln. Last week also saw the third consecutive lower weekly reading, but analysts believe that it will be still several more weeks before the rate of claims falls beneath 1mln.
  • In terms of the implications for the April employment situation report, last week’s jobless claims coincided with the BLS’ jobs report survey period, and Pantheon’s tentative forecasts look for nonfarm payrolls to shed around 21mln jobs in the month, and May payrolls seen declining by 9mln; Pantheon believes that the June report will largely depend on how far states are able to re-open their economies, especially in the discretionary consumer services sector, where most of the first wave of jobs disappeared after the lockdowns.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 30th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are subdued after a modestly positive start; FTSE 100 & energy names after Shell cut quarterly dividend
  • US President Trump said China will do anything they can for him to lose the 2020 election and stated the US is looking at different options regarding consequences for China
  • Chinese official Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMIs fell short of estimates but Non-Manufacturing and Composite PMIs both improved
  • US President Trump said they will have a plan to support oil companies soon while IEA’s Birol warned storage could be full by mid-June
  • FX sees the USD softer with GBP the main beneficiary on both technical and month-end demand
  • Looking ahead, highlights ECB policy announcement & press conference, US initial jobless claims, Canadian GDP, Chicago PMI

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said Federal Reserve programmes should be broad based and not industry-focused, while he added there are no plans for additional money for airlines at this time. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson is to dash hopes that the lockdown could be lifted soon and will warn the country today not to expect major changes to restrictions as UK risks having among the world's worst death rates. (Telegraph) Note, the next scheduled review for the lockdown is on May 7th. However, a separate article in the Telegraph notes that a blueprint for ending the lockdown could be unveiled as soon as Monday. UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 26,097 in which deaths increased by 765 (578 hospital vs. yesterday’s 586). (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. and Oxford Uni announce landmark agreement for a COVID-19 vaccine, aims to secure CHADOX1 vaccine potential to patients. Co. would, under this agreement, be responsible for the worldwide manufacturing and distribution. CEO says the Co. should have a good idea in June or July whether its COVID-19 vaccine works; any vaccine would be provided at cost. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel's Chief of Staff says social distancing measures will "certainly" be extended until 10th May, via Bild Newspaper. German Public Health Ministry estimates the R0 for COVID-19 in Germany at 0.76.

Italian PM Conte says the government will work with regions so that they can ease coronavirus restrictions, depending on local conditions. (Newswires)

Spain's coronavirus deaths rise by 268 to 24,543 (Prev. 24,275), according to the Health Ministry.

Tokyo has 46 new cases of COVID-19, according to media reports. (Newswires) Japan's PM has reportedly decided to extend the deadline, originally May 6th, for deciding upon an extension to the deceleration of emergency, Kyodo. Japanese gov't is to create a fund with up to JPY 1tln set aside for capital injections for SMEs, Nikkei reports

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positively as the region took impetus from the gains on Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by coronavirus treatment hopes after preliminary results from Gilead’s Remdesivir drug trial showed a 31% faster recovery time and lower mortality rate compared to patients that were given a placebo. Furthermore, the Fed reiterated to keep supporting the economy as necessary and encouraging earnings from several tech heavyweights after-market briefly added fuel to the momentum for US index futures. ASX 200 (+2.4%) was lifted by strength in the energy sector as oil prices continued to make up ground and with a slew of corporate updates in focus. Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) outperformed as it played catch up on return from the holiday closure and as a weaker currency provided an uplift to exporter sentiment, while Industrial Production and Retail Sales data were not as bad as had been feared despite both printing in contraction territory. Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) was also positive ahead of the extended 5-day weekend in the mainland for Labor Day holidays and amid several blue chip earnings, although gains were somewhat capped by the absence of Hong Kong participants and following mixed Chinese PMI data in which official Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMIs fell short of estimates but Non-Manufacturing and Composite PMIs both improved. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre with demand subdued by gains in riskier assets and following a similar uninspired tone in T-notes, while the absence of the BoJ in the market today and resistance ahead of the 153.00 level also ensured the mundane price action.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0571 vs. Exp. 7.0618 (Prev. 7.0707) PBoC will reportedly offer long term funding through RRR and MLF next month, according to Chinese press.

US President Trump said China will do anything they can for him to lose the 2020 election and stated the US is looking at different options regarding consequences for China for its handling of coronavirus crisis in which he suggested he could do a lot. Furthermore, US President Trump stated the US trade deal with China has been upset very badly by coronavirus, while he doesn't see elections as a referendum of his handling of the crisis and doesn't believe polls showing Biden is ahead. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 50.8 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 52.0). Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 53.2 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.3) Chinese Composite PMI (Apr) 53.4 (Prev. 53.0) Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 49.4 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.1); Export Orders fell by the fastest pace since the GFC and employment declined further.

Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) M/M -3.7% vs. Exp. -5.2% (Prev. -0.3%). (Newswires) Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -5.2% vs. Exp. -7.4% (Prev. 5.7%)

US

US NEC Director Kudlow stated the economic contraction is going to go on for a bit although he predicts a growing and recovering economy by summertime. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU GDP Flash Prelim QQ (Q1) -3.8% vs. Exp. -3.5% (Prev. 0.1%)

-        EU GDP Flash Prelim YY (Q1) -3.3% vs. Exp. -3.1% (Prev. 1.0%)

EU HICP Flash YY (Apr) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.7%)

-        EU HICP-X Food & Energy Flash YY (Apr) 1.1% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.2%)

-        EU HICP-X Food, Energy, Alcohol & Tobacco Flash YY (Apr) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 1.0%)

EQUITIES

European equities waned off highs since the cash open (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%) and failed to sustain the momentum from a positive APAC handover, as markets digest a slew of earnings and sets sights on the ECB’s policy announcement later (Full preview available on the Research Suite). Overall, bourses trade mixed with mild outperformance in the CAC 40 (+0.1%) – aided by the likes of Safran (+1.7%) post-earnings and Airbus (+5.4%) as shares are underpinned after its CEO noted the group is in talks with French states – yesterday Finance Minister Le Maire said the gov’t could aid Airbus if the time is right. Sectors remain mixed and do not reflect a clear risk tone. Energy is the clear laggard as Shell (-6.3%) plumbs the depths post-earnings, afflicting the FTSE 100, after the group cut dividends for the first time since 1945 amid the oil price slump. The sector breakdown is similarly diverse but sees Travel & Leisure as the top amid hopes of looser global lockdown measures. Individual movers again largely consist of post-earning action; Lloyds (-5.9%) remains pressured after reporting a slump in Q1 pre-tax profit alongside a rise in impairments of around GBP 1.2bln YY. BASF (-1.0%) is lower after missing on Adj, EBITDA expectations, and cutting Q1 EPS to EUR 0.96/shr from EUR 1.53/shr whilst withdrawing guidance. Orange (+1.1%) holds onto opening gains as the group does not expect to significantly deviate from its FY targets. BBVA (-1.5%) holds onto losses after reporting an impairment charge of over EUR 2bln. Finally, AstraZeneca (+3.3%) sees upside after the Co. and Oxford Uni announce landmark agreement for a COVID-19 vaccine, aims to secure CHADOX1 vaccine potential to patients. Co. would, under this agreement, be responsible for the worldwide manufacturing and distribution – with the CEO stating it should have a good idea in June or July whether its COVID-19 vaccine works.

USD 5.293bln, of which. Shareholder attributable loss of USD 24mln. Not continuing with next tranche of share buyback. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The Dollar is holding up relatively well in wake of the FOMC and presser from Fed Chair Powell that was forthright in terms of appraising the sever economic impact of the coronavirus containment efforts and the high probability that even more stimulus will be required, monetary and fiscal, to try and ensure a robust post-pandemic recovery. Moreover, the Greenback remains prone to further month-end outflows for rebalancing purposes and erosion of safe-haven premium given buoyant risk sentiment based on hopes for an anti-COVID-19 treatment and/or vaccine. S&P cut South Africa by one notch to BB-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FIXED

Core bonds maintain upside momentum into month end with new highs posted above prior resistance levels and April peaks awaiting the ECB for potential fresh direction. Italian BTPs look especially expectant and in need of a revival but may be disappointed in the event. Also ahead, US data including the next instalment of weekly claims and Chicago PMIs as a precursor to ISM on Friday.

COMMODITIES

Energy contracts wane off best levels as European trades goes underway, but nonetheless remain firmly in positive territory, with WTI June +14% just above USD 17/bbl (intraday range USD 15.45-17.75/bbl) while the Brent July contract sees gains of around 8%, with prices just north of USD 26/bbl (intraday range USD 24.41-26.66.bbl). In terms of fresh developments, Norway Oil Ministry said Norway will be cutting oil output by 250k BOE/D in June and then lowered to 134k BPD in H2 until year-end, while the start-up of production at several fields will be delayed until 2021 and that production in December 2020 will be 300k BPD less than originally planned. Meanwhile, over in the US, Texas regulators released details on a proposed order to cut Texan output by around 1mln BPD, with a potential vote next week. Albeit, Texas Railroad Commission Chairman Christian said he still opposes mandated oil production cuts to address global oil curb. Elsewhere, US President Trump said they will have a plan to support oil companies soon. Other reports also noted the Trump administration is close to rolling out new lending facilities to help oil and gas companies struggling from a collapse in prices. Amongst all this, IEA’s Chief Birol warned that global storage could be full by mid-June and called on OPEC+ to mull further cuts, with the initial pact set to officially come into effect tomorrow. Elsewhere, spot gold sees modest gains as equities pull back from highs, with the yellow metal towards the top of its daily band of USD 1709.79-1719.66/oz. Base metals focus on lower mining output and the prospect of economies reopening for business, with Copper prices firmer on the day, albeit off highs, as the red metal meanders around mid-range at USD 2.4/lb and Zinc rallying some 2% in overnight trade.

IEA's Birol warned that global oil storage could be full by mid-June and called on OPEC+ countries to consider more cuts. (Twitter)

US President Trump said they will have a plan to support oil companies soon. Other reports also noted the Trump administration is close to rolling out new lending facilities to help oil and gas companies struggling from a collapse in prices. The program which is still under development, would primarily consist of the US Treasury Department offering bridge loans to help the industry through this pandemic and the Federal Reserve offering emergency lending under the so-called Section 13(3) program, while US Energy Secretary Dan Brouillette stated the lending facilities were not meant for "big players" in the sector that have other sources of capital. (Newswires/Argus) US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that the administration is looking at a lot of strategies for the energy industry but rules out a bailout for oil companies, while Mnuchin added the administration is exploring having the ability to store another several hundred million barrels of oil. (Newswires)

Texas Railroad Commission Chairman Christian said he still opposes mandated oil production cuts to address global oil curbs and noted that state producers are cutting output although a 20% reduction in Texas will not impact global supplies. (Newswires)

Norway Oil Ministry said Norway will be cutting oil output by 250k BOE/D in June and 134k in H2, while the startup of production at several fields will be delayed until 2021 and that production in December 2020 will be 300k BPD less than originally planned. (Newswires) Norwegian gov't has proposed measures to stimulate investments by the energy industry - will propose significant tax measures to secure oil industry activity.

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Stocks slip, crude climbs and bonds brace for ECB - 30th April 2020
content:

EQUITIES

European equities waned off highs since the cash open (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%) and failed to sustain the momentum from a positive APAC handover, as markets digest a slew of earnings and sets sights on the ECB’s policy announcement later (Full preview available on the Research Suite). Overall, bourses trade mixed with mild outperformance in the CAC 40 (+0.1%) – aided by the likes of Safran (+1.7%) post-earnings and Airbus (+5.4%) as shares are underpinned after its CEO noted the group is in talks with French states – yesterday Finance Minister Le Maire said the gov’t could aid Airbus if the time is right. Sectors remain mixed and do not reflect a clear risk tone. Energy is the clear laggard as Shell (-6.3%) plumbs the depths post-earnings, afflicting the FTSE 100, after the group cut dividends for the first time since 1945 amid the oil price slump. The sector breakdown is similarly diverse but sees Travel & Leisure as the top amid hopes of looser global lockdown measures. Individual movers again largely consist of post-earning action; Lloyds (-5.9%) remains pressured after reporting a slump in Q1 pre-tax profit alongside a rise in impairments of around GBP 1.2bln YY. BASF (-1.0%) is lower after missing on Adj, EBITDA expectations, and cutting Q1 EPS to EUR 0.96/shr from EUR 1.53/shr whilst withdrawing guidance. Orange (+1.1%) holds onto opening gains as the group does not expect to significantly deviate from its FY targets. BBVA (-1.5%) holds onto losses after reporting an impairment charge of over EUR 2bln. Other earnings-related movers include Swiss Re (-2.5%), Deutsche Boerse (+2.6%), Nokia (+3.7%) and Danske Bank (-1.8%)  Elsewhere, Wirecard (+4.8%) rises as its chairman does not see CEO Braun behind replaced, which follows activist Hohn’s call to remove the CEO. Finally, AstraZeneca (+3.3%) sees upside after the Co. and Oxford Uni announce landmark agreement for a COVID-19 vaccine, aims to secure CHADOX1 vaccine potential to patients. Co. would, under this agreement, be responsible for the worldwide manufacturing and distribution – with the CEO stating it should have a good idea in June or July whether its COVID-19 vaccine works.

FX                                                                                     

USD - The Dollar is holding up relatively well in wake of the FOMC and presser from Fed Chair Powell that was forthright in terms of appraising the sever economic impact of the coronavirus containment efforts and the high probability that even more stimulus will be required, monetary and fiscal, to try and ensure a robust post-pandemic recovery. Moreover, the Greenback remains prone to further month-end outflows for rebalancing purposes and erosion of safe-haven premium given buoyant risk sentiment based on hopes for an anti-COVID-19 treatment and/or vaccine. However, the DXY is managing to stay within proximity of the 99.500 level that has been pivotal within recent ranges and is still keeping the index resistant on approach towards 99.000.

CHF/GBP - The major “outperformers”, albeit amidst quite restrained parameters overall, as the Franc inches closer to 0.9700 and further away from 1.0600 vs. the Euro, while Cable rebounds towards 1.2500 and Eur/Gbp recoils towards 0.8700 on a mix of month end demand and technical factors. Note, one bank model is pointing to outsize Sterling demand vs. the Buck and especially from 1500BST to 1600BST when fund managers re-hedge stock portfolios, while the cross is back below the 200DMA again.

CAD/EUR - Another upturn in oil prices has helped the Loonie consolidate gains above 1.3900 and almost match the current mtd peak not far from 1.3850 ahead of Canadian data comprising monthly GDP and PPI, while the Euro is still meeting resistance ahead of 1.0900 and last week’s apex just shy of the round number, though also finding underlying bids on dips despite more downbeat Eurozone data in the run-up to ECB.

JPY - The Yen also looks locked between decent option expiries and a key chart level that was marginally breached on Wednesday, while many Japanese participants were otherwise engaged given a market holiday on the penultimate trading session of April, but did not trigger stops to test 106.00. Subsequently, Usd/Jpy is meandering between 106.87-42 and back above the aforementioned technical mark (50% Fib retracement at 106.45).

AUD/NZD - Aud lost impetus around 100 DMA at 0.6567, and mega 2.7 bn expiry at 0.6570. Nzd hampered by bleak NBNZ Biz survey.

content: Another blank UK agenda and no further clarity about the timing of any re-opening or relaxation of coronavirus restrictions has left UK debt and STIR futures rather indifferent and lacklustre at the start of the last session of the month. 3 month contracts have been mostly on the defensive since the Liffe open and -2 ticks to just +0.5 tick vs Wednesday’s settlement levels, while the 10 year bond lags peers between 137.20-136.95 parameters compared to its 137.10 prior close. Perhaps debt futures are still taking on board the scale of DMO supply in store over the next 3 months and acknowledging the tapered issuance calendar, but if April’s auctions are a reliable guide then there seems little to fear in terms of demand. From a technical standpoint, nearest resistance remains at 137.45 (last Friday’s high), with support further below 137.00 at 136.74 (this Monday’s low).

Bunds: back in the ascendency as April draws to a close
content: Irrespective of broader risk sentiment that remains constructive if not gung-ho, the 10 year German benchmark has recovered from an opening markdown and dip to resume its rebound towards peaks not seen since the very start of the month. Bunds have lost some momentum ahead of the EU cash bourse opens, but remain comfortably above 173.00 within a 173.33-172.94 range vs yesterday’s 173.06 close and closer to the 173.48 Eurex high from April 1 that would complete a round trip if matched at some stage before the end of the session. However, peripheral peers also perky ahead of the ECB and more data that could be pivotal in terms of direction, like US weekly claims and the Chicago PMIs as proxies for NFP and ISM.

subject: UK Justice Minister Buckland says you will not be hearing specific detail regarding lockdown easing later today
analysis_details: • Morning press highlights that: UK PM Johnson is to dash hopes that the lockdown could be lifted soon and will warn the country today not to expect major changes to restrictions as UK risks having among the world's worst death rates. (Telegraph) Note, the next scheduled review for the lockdown is on May 7th. subject: AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. and Oxford Uni announce landmark agreement for a COVID-19 vaccine, aims to secure CHADOX1 vaccine potential to patients. Co. would, under this agreement, be responsible for the worldwide manufacturing and distribution.
analysis_details:
Follows on from:

  • GILEAD announced results from its own SIMPLE study of Remdisivir used in severe COVID-19 patients, which showed similar effects for 5-day treatment against 10-day; additionally it announced that it is aware that the drug had met its primary endpoint from the government (NIAID) study (results due Wednesday at 1700 ET). The announcements, akin to prior Remsidivir updates, saw equity bourses rally, although discussion revolves around whether the optimism is premature. Firstly, the severe patients study success will only be constructive if the drug passes on a safety and efficacy basis – something which the government (NIAID) study should provide some insight on, although as of yet, it is not quite clear if the study is testing for both bases. If the government study proves that the drug fails on safety/efficacy, then the difference between 5-day and 10-day treatment will be meaningless, but on the contrary, if the drug passes, then today’s results would mean greater supply available as patients would require less of the treatment, hence optimising its availability. Sceptics also draw attention to the fact that the Gilead trial results announced today had a 9% fatality rate, or 39 deaths, which appears only a moderate improvement to the natural death rate from the virus, although the sample size is small and thus drawing conclusions in general from the results are difficult. Instead, the wider government study to be released tonight should provide a greater understanding, and optimist on the drug allude to the fact that White House officials, including President Trump, have pre-announced that the results will be released and drawn attention to the study – see Fauci comments below – which could be indicative of success in the trial.
  • NIH DIRECTOR FAUCI said preliminary Remdesivir results indicate patients who received the drug had a 31% faster recovery time than those with a placebo (note that the statistical significance of such claims remain cloudy). Fauci said it showed Remdesivir accelerated recovery from advanced COVID-19 cases. The preliminary results suggested a survival benefit with a mortality rate of 8% for the group receiving Remdesivir vs 11.6% for those with a placebo. Median recovery times was 11 days for those with Remdesivir, compared to 15 days for those who received a placebo, Fauci said.
